introduction: This report provides a series of summary charts, statistics and other details about the mobilization and use of open-access species data through the GBIF network at global and national scales. These metrics represent change over the past 12 months, unless otherwise noted. Taken together, the elements of this report can help guide and measure progress toward the information needs for national and international commitments on biodiversity and sustainable development.
numPeerReviedPublicationsCitingGBIF: Number of peer-reviewed publications citing use of global GBIF-mediated data
dataDownloadsFromUsersIn: Data downloads on GBIF.org from users in
numOccDownloadsByOrgsIn: Number of occurrence records downloaded via GBIF.org published by institutions in
recentPeerReviewedArticles: Recent peer-reviewed articles using GBIF-mediated data by co-authors based in
theGBIFSecretariatMaintansAndReports: The GBIF Secretariat maintains and reports on an ongoing literature tracking programme, giving priority to substantive uses of GBIF-mediated data in peer-reviewed literature while identifying the countries of the authors’ institutional a liations. The citations below represent the five most recent journal articles with at least one co-author from this country.
thoseInterestedInAssisting: Those interested in assisting the Secretariat in identifying additional peer-reviewed uses of GBIF-mediated data may forward relevant citations to

numRecordsSharedOverTime: The chart above shows the number of records shared over time by publishers within the country, with separate colours for records about species occurring within the country and those occurring in other countries.
ofAllDownloads: of all downloads during the reporting period

whyDecrease: WHY MIGHT THE AMOUNT OF MOBILIZED DATA DECREASE?
whyDecreaseAnswer: Datasets are sometimes removed by publishers, but more often decreases in the number of records are due to the removal of duplicate records and datasets.
